There's a huge difference between using and abusing nature.
 
 Using nature for wood could be done sustainable and relatively easily. We're using nature for our own means without causing long-term damage to the environment.
 
 Abusing nature for wood could be done by felling a rainforest. We're abusing nature here (as well as shooting ourselves in the foot by getting rid of a huge source of possible new medicines).
 
 If the savoir of a rainforest means that 50 people are unemployed by slightly higher costs of wood, then personally, I don't mind. Does that mean I put plant/animal life before human life? No. However when minor damage is done to humans, which has a massive impact on preserving the environment, then chances are I'd support it.
 
 Another example is whaling. I believe that some types of whales shouldn't be killed, seeing as I think that the species should be able to recover fully before they're hunted again. That may mean that some people become unemployed, but being honest, that's a small price to pay for preserving a species. Yes again, does that mean I put animal/plan t life before human life? No. It means that a small amount of damage done to humans has a huge impact in preserving a whole set of species.
 
 That's not "anti-every-human-economic-activity greens". That's wanting to preserve the environment.
 
 An example of where I don't support greens is those who destroy lobster cages/ restaurants. That is and example of "anti-every-human economic-activity greens", seeing as lobsters (afaik) don't actually feel pain and as such trying to "save" them from non-existent pain seems retarded to me.
 
 Also, as Clive said, you describe the actions of moderate greens as those who are "anti-every-human-economic-activity greens".
